title: brexit amendments explained mps vote
story: NewsBrexit vote amendments explained as Theresa May faces Valentines Day defeatTheresa May is facing another House of Commons showdown over Brexit. Her Valentines Day massacre was meant to be more of a love-in - but she faces defeat. Heres what to expectShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsShes not facing a total Valentines Day massacre - but it aint a love-in either "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is holding yet another round of Brexit votes from pm of Thursday  February. Just  days before Brexit, the PM has tabled a motion asking MPs to reiterate the support for her strategy that they expressed two weeks ago. But she faces defeat. And meanwhile MPs are tabling three amendments which would give them a chance to back a radically dferent approach instead. Its a re-run of two weeks ago, when MPs voted to reject the prospect of No Deal , and agreed to back the dealthe Irish border backstop can be fixed. The House of Commons showdown was originally billed a Valentines Day massacre where MPs could strip out core details of her plan for leaving the EU. Then it appeared MPs had backed off - in full knowledge that therell be another clash in two weeks from now. But she now faces a suprise defeat at the hands of Tory Brexiteers...  Heres how today works. Theresa May tables a statement. MPs then table amendments to it. Usually the amendments are the danger area. But Tory Brexiteers arent actually exercised about the amendments to her statement. Instead theyre cross about the statement itself - even though it has no legal force. It says: That this House reiterates its support for the approach to leaving the EU expressed by this House on  January . The problem is, the Commons agreed two things on January . One was to renegotiate the Irish backstop - a clause which could extend EU customs rules over the UK. Brexiteers are fine with this. The second was to reject the prospect of a No Deal Brexit. Brexiteers are not fine with this at all. Defeat on this motion wont have any legal force. But it will kneecap Theresa May in her talks with the EU, because it will show she doesnt have a united parliament behind her. Here are the  amendments she faces  Stop Tories running down the clock  Labours Jeremy Corbyn has an amendment that would stop the Prime Minister running down the clock. The bid would force the government to hold a full meaningful vote on the new Brexit deal by February  - or admit there is no longer a deal. If the government admitted there was no longer a deal, it would need to make a new statement on what happens next. It comes after ministers admitted MPs may only get their final meaningful vote a few days before the March  date of Brexit. Labour MPs fear that will blackmail them into choosing either Theresa Mays deal or a disastrous No Deal Brexit .  Delay the date of Brexit The SNPs Ian Blackford is seeking to extend the date of Brexit by no fewer than three months. This would have to be agreed with the EU, with whom extension talks would begin immediately.  Reveal secret No Deal briefing documents  Cross-party Remainers including Anna Soubry want to reveal the impact of no deal. Their amendment would instruct the government to publish the most recent official briefing document given to the Cabinet on the implications of No Deal on business and trade. The document would have to be published within seven days. Heres the threat coming soon Force the PM to rule out No Deal   NOTE: This amendment is not being laid THIS week - itll only be put forward towards the end of February. Labour MP Yvette Cooper is leading a fresh bid to rule out No Deal Brexit - after her previous attempt was defeated by MPs. Under her plan,there is still no Brexit deal by March , Prime Minister Theresa May must put no deal to a formal vote. MPs would then be able to vote to block a No Deal Brexit, choosing instead to extend the March  date of Brexit. Labours Brexit chief Sir Keir Starmer said the party will support Ms Cooper again, like they did two weeks ago. But hell have to convince some of the  Labour rebels who refused to back her last time to change their minds. A source said the amendment is being held back for now, because Tories clearly want one final opportunity to get a deal. “So it’s likely that it will be put to a vote at the end of the month, rather than now. At that stage, there are likely to be Tory resignations over it, the source said.  And here are the amendments that didnt make the cut The following amendments will not face a vote because they were not selected by Speaker John Bercow. Hold a ballot of MPs on the options  Remain-backing Tory grandee Ken Clarke is leading a bid for MPs to hold a vote on their preferences for the way forward. Under his plan, they would rank dferent options from  to X on a ballot paper - a highly unusual procedure. Any option could go on the ballot paperat least  MPs have backed it in advance. It comes days after the Tory MP was spotted having a curry with Commons Speaker John Bercow. We wouldnt possibly suggest the Speaker had something to say about this unusual ballot plan. Cancel the date of Brexit  SNP MP Angus Brendan MacNeil is leading a bid to cancel the  March date of Brexit. His amendment calls on the government to urgently revoke the Article  notication, which set a two-year countdown to our leaving the EU back in . Under EU rules, Article  cant be extended without getting permission from all  EU leaders. But it can be revoked completely on the UKs decision alone. Delay the date of Brexit Labours Geraint Davies is seeking to extend the date of Brexit with the option of a future public vote. Let MPs vote on a series of set options Cross-party Remainers led by Sarah Wollaston, the Tory GP and MP, want to gold a series of indicative votes on the shape of a future deal. The options would be:Theresa Mays deal as it stands A No Deal Brexit Theresa Mays deal with backstop changes A Canada-style deal Norway plus, staying in EFTA A second EU referendumHold a second EU referendum  Labour MP Roger Godsf is leading a fresh bid to force a second EU referendum. Under his plan, the March  Brexit date would be delayed while a second referendum is arranged. The referendum would then have three questions on the ballot paper - Theresa Mays deal, No Deal, or stay in the EU. The referendum would use the alternative vote system, where the least popular option is eliminated and second preferences are then re-allocated to decide the winner. Plaid Cymrus Jonathan Edwards is also leading a bid to hold a binding second referendum on EU membership. And Lib Dem leader Sir Vince Cable wants to delay the date of Brexit in order to hold a second EU referendum.

title: brexit party leader branded distasteful
story: NewsBrexit Party leader branded distasteful after claiming foodbanks make kids obeseCatherine Blaiklock - whose movement is backed by Nigel Farage - complained emergency handouts for families on the brink are full of “sweet custard and PopTarts”ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsMs Blaiklock, who owns a guest house in Norfolk, made the comments last month in an article for The Conservative Woman website "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe leader of Nigel Farage’s new Brexit Party has been branded out of touch after claiming food banks are making kids obese. Ex-city worker Catherine Blaiklock moaned emergency handouts are full of “sweet custard and PopTarts” and people “cannot even be bothered to buy their hungry children an egg.The former UKIP candidate was named last week as the leader of the Brexit Party, which is supported by Nigel Farage and claims to have gained , supporters in its first  hours.Ms Blaiklock, who owns a guest house in Norfolk, made the comments last month in an article for The Conservative Woman website. She complained about the “contradiction” between stories of people going hungry and an obesity epidemic   In the article, titled Let them eat spuds, she claimed nutritious food in the UK is very cheap and available in vast quantities, but many people lead chaotic lives or cannot cook. She added: A visit to a food bank of the type that millions are supposed to rely on shows you the problem. It is full of cans of sweet custard and packets of PopTarts and the like. They do not stock raw potatoes because they might ‘go off’. She added: Food banks should stop, think and go back to the drawing board. Kind as they may be, they are not doing society or their beneficiaries any favours. They are creating a dependent, obese population. Teaching their recipients how to shop for raw ingredients and to cook ‘meat and two veg’ would be more helpful.  Margaret Greenwood, Labours Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary, said: These comments are distasteful and show just how out of touch this party really is. A Trussell Trust spokeswoman said the average user of the foodbank charity came just twice a year. Many foodbanks in our network do offer fresh food where they are able to safely store, a spokeswoman said. For example, fruit, vegetables, eggs and bread, and this is something we’re working with our network to develop further. Asked for comment by the Mirror, Ms Blaiklock said she was comparing the price of food in Nepal and the UK after living there and marrying a Nepalese man.  She added: [Anti-poverty campaigner] Jack Munroe has said exactly the same thing about simple basic cooking and was not criticised. Jamie Oliver has also said similar things. It comes after BuzzFeed News revealed earlier this week that Ms Blaiklock had made anti-Muslim comments in online articles. In one blog post about burqas she wrote: There are currently  majority Muslim countries in the world. If these people really dislike it so much in the West, why do they chose to live here  In another article she wrote: There is also some truth in the statement that Muslim men were impregnating white British girls to create Muslim babies”. Ms Blaiklock told BuzzFeed she was highlighting the point about radical Islam not liking our way of le. Is that not entirely uncontroversial

title: brexit tories joke valentines poem
story: NewsBrexit: Tories joke with Valentines poem while driving Commons into a car crashAndrea Leadsom had MPs groaning with her light-hearted rhyme - while all the while were running out of time for BrexitShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video andrea-leadsom-jokes-around-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A top Tory joked around with a cringeworthy Valentines Day poem today... just as she was accused of driving MPs into a Brexit car crash.Andrea Leadsom read out the light-heated rhyme about Britains bright future with a good deal the House of Commons. But the Commons Leader did it while unveiling Parliaments business for next week - which experts say is drastically behind schedule. With  days left before Brexit, the Hansard Society says just  of  expected Statutory Instruments have been laid. They are crucial technical laws that ensure our legal system doesnt collapse on March there is No Deal. One of the SIs alone is  pages long and weighs several kilogrammes.   Ms Leadsom said around three SIs per day will be debated per day on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday after MPs were ordered back from their February break. Others will be pushed through behind the scenes. But there will be none in the Commons chamber on Thursday - with MPs instead having a general debate on trade agreements with the US, New Zealand and Australia that dont yet exist.Ms Leadsom joked:Labour is red.   Tories are blue.Our future is bright with a good deal in sight   For the UK and our friends in the EU. But SNP MP Pete Wishart fumed: They’re all going to be missing their skiing holidays and villas for this There’s only  days before we’re supposed to leave the EU. This is getting beyond a joke and this government is taking this House for mugs. Shadow Commons leader Valerie Vaz said: This is really serious. Each week there is chaos. This is an appalling way to govern a country.  And Mr Wishart shot back: Labour is red   Tories are blue   The message from Scotland is we’re staying in the EU! The Best For Britain campaign group, which opposes Brexit, claimed the government will need to lay seven SIs per day to meet its target. The group claimed , pages of SIs have been written. And with the average number of pages per SI in January being , over  SIs that means there are still , pages to be written, Best For Britain claimed. Backer Layla Moran, a Lib Dem MP, said: We were supposed to be taking back control but we are actually heading towards to a democratic car crash. The government is just trying to ride roughshod over scrutiny. No-one, whether you voted leave or remain, voted for this.

title: confront your local mp over
story: NewsConfront your local MP over brutal Tory welfare regime, John McDonnell declaresEXCLUSIVE: The Shadow Chancellor told a campaign meeting its now "unchallengeable" that the system can be linked to peoples deaths - and many MPs still dont "get it"ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe Shadow Chancellor called for the direct action as he claimed it is now unchallengeable that the system can be linked to peoples deaths "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn McDonnell has urged people to confront their local MP in person over the Tories disability benefits regime. The Shadow Chancellor called for the direct action as he claimed it is now unchallengeable that the system can be linked to peoples deaths - and many MPs still dont get it.He spoke to dozens of disability activists who met in Parliament yesterday to debate flaws in disability assessments and Universal Credit .In a wide-ranging speech John McDonnell told attendees all-in-one benefit Universal Credit was inflicting brutality and also criticised sanctions and disability benefit assessments. He said the PIP process, ESA process is pushing people to the edge. He called on those affected to confront their MPs in person. When theres a general debate, they dont seem to get it, the Shadow Chancellor said.  But when its face to face, these are the numbers in your constituency, and by the way Id like to introduce you to someone whos been sanctioned, we begin at least to get some appreciation. Later in his speech, he added: I dont think theres any understanding of the urgency. People are dying. When you say people are dying, with the number of suicides, Liverpool University research, the stuff that was produced in the Lancet - , impacted upon, journalists never, never believe you when you say that. But when you actually then say well Ill give you a case, heres one that happened in our area that we know about, eventually theres a little bit of awareness.  A Liverpool University study in  found the work capability assessment programme for ESA was independently associated with an increase in suicides, self-reported mental health problems and anti-depressant prescribing. However, the NHS later said of the study: The study can only demonstrate associations between the data. We cannot say for sure that the WCAs were the direct cause of the mental health outcomes examined. A  study in BMJ Open said austerity was linked to , extra deaths in England. However, it appeared to attribute health and social care cuts rather than the benefits system. Asked to claryhe was saying welfare policies can be directly linked to peoples deaths, Mr McDonnell told the Mirror: Its not just me saying that, its academic research thats been undertaken over recent years. Its unchallengeable now. The Department for Work and Pensionshas previously repeatedly said benefit policies cannot be linked directly to deaths.  The meeting was called to discuss flaws in the disability benefit system but Universal Credit featured heavily too. Mr McDonnell accepted new DWP chief Amber Rudd is now arguing for reform - but warned it must not just be publicity stunts and press releases. He added: I dont want to comment on Esther McVey, but thank God shes gone. Mr McDonnell infamously quoted someone who had said they wanted to lynch the then-DWP minister in . He told the meeting: All those years of just asking her to produce the information... made people so angry. And some go over the top and I got into trouble for that, but there you are.  Disability activist Catherine Hale told the meeting disabled people become paralysed with dread about receiving a letter notying them of an assessment. And on Universal Credit she added: Everything about Universal Credit creates a hostile environment for disabled people. There is no redeeming feature of Universal Credit that makes it worth keeping and tweaking. Universal Credit must be scrapped. What about Universal Basic Income as an alternative  Activist Mark Harrison added: What we require is a scrapping of Universal Credit. Meanwhile John McArdle, of the Black Triangle campaign which collates what it calls welfare-related deaths, said: I dont think anybody reasonably can deny the direct link between the Work Capability Assessment and people dying in destitution and from suicide. The Secretary of State might deny that, but the members of this House of Parliament cant deny that.   Sanctions were also criticised at the meeting, where attendees were told there was no evidence they helped people back into work. Gill Thompson, whose brother David Clapsons death was highly publicised in , told the meeting: I do feel thathe hadnt been sanctioned, he might still be here. Shadow Minister for Disabled People Marsha De Cordova slammed the system as callous and mean, saying the Tories are still shamelessly in power despite the cruel sanctions regime. She told attendees the system is littered with errors, adding: They have created what has become a hostile environment.A Conservative Party spokesman said: “ Labour created ESA which was supposed to end the perverse incentives in the old Incapacity Benefit but instead introduced new ones.“Whereas we’ve introduced Universal Credit which is targeted towards those who need support. “As a result around  million disabled households will gain on average around pound more per month on Universal Credit, compared to the old system. “We’re spending more pound billion this year on benefits to support disabled people and those with health conditions.“

title: tory brexit truce brink collapsing
story: NewsBrexit: Tory truce faces collapse as Theresa May braces for Valentines Day defeatTonights vote was meant to be a love-in - but Tory Brexiteers are furious that theyre being asked to back a motion that commits to avoiding no dealShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsTonights vote was tipped to be a love-in - but instead Theresa Mays negotiating mandate could be thrown into chaos "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tory truce over Brexit faces collapse as Theresa May faced a fresh bruising Commons defeat by her Brexiteers. Tonights vote was tipped to be a love-in after the Prime Minister begged for more time to negotiate her Brexit deal with the EU. But hardline MPs are furious at being forced to vote on her motion, which is legally powerless - but politically crucial. Because of the way Commons motions work, the Brexteers, led by Jacob Rees-Mogg, claim they will be locked into avoiding a No-Deal departurethey back Mrs May tonight. So they are expected to rebel - throwing the supposed mandate for Mrs Mays talks with Brussels back into chaos. Although she can carry on trying to negotiate with the EU, Brussels chiefs are less likely to give groundthey think Mrs May doesnt have a united Parliament behind her. Trade Secretary Liam Fox warned: I think that our European partners will be watching to see,they make those concessions, do they think that parliament would be likely then to pass that agreement  MPs will hold a series of non-binding votes from pm, another chance to have their say on the Prime Minister’s Brexit plans.   MPs will be asked to confirm they still back the approach to leaving the EU that was passed by a stormy Commons on January . MPs backed an amendment that forced Mrs May to try to renegotiate the Irish border backstop - a clause in the -page Brexit deal which would trap us under EU rules - with Brussels. But on the same day, they also passed one which ruled out crashing out without a Brexit deal. Several MPs in the hardline European Reform Group have warned Tory whips that they will not support the PM’s plan. Mark Francois, ERG vice-chair, said: “We cannot vote for this as it is currently configured because it rules out no deal and removes our negotiating leverage in Brussels... It is madness.”  But the PM’s official spokesman said: “No-deal is an eventuality we wish to avoid, but one we continue to plan for. Does no-deal remain on the table  The answer is yes.” The latest showdown comes as European Council president Donald Tusk expressed frustration at a lack of progress. He tweeted: No news is not always good news. EU still waiting for concrete, realistic proposals from London on how to break #Brexitimpasse. Meanwhile, Government ministers were desperately back-pedalling over claims the PM was running down the clock to blackmail MPs with the threat of a no deal. Her top Brexit aide Olly Robbins was overheard in a Brussels bar claiming MPs would get a last-minute choice to back the PM’s Brexit plan - or delay Brexit day.   Mrs May dismissed his remarks as “something said by someone  overheard by someone  in a bar”. She added: “We want to leave with a deal. That is what we are working for.” Senior Tories scrambled to insist that Brexit would happen on time. Tory vice-chairman Chris Philp said: “What a civil servant might speculate in a bar after a few drinks is frankly not that important.” Shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer accused the PM of brinkmanship - and warned of a “concerted” cross-party effort to get an extensionher deal fails. He threw the party’s weight behind a new version of Labour MP Yvette Cooper’s plan to delay Brexit.  MPs could also get a vote on an amendment by veteran Tory Ken Clarke to allow MPs to vote for their preferred Brexit outcome. More cross-party talks took place today with Sir Keir and Labour’s Jon Trickett meeting Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay and de facto deputy PM David Lidington. Meanwhile Labour faced a new split over whether to swing behind a second EU referendum. Sir Keir was slapped down by the leadership after suggesting a general election - Labour’s preferred option - was no longer viable. He said a second referendum was the only “credible option” leftLabour’s favoured Brexit deal can’t be agreed.   Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell admitted to the Mirror it would now be “very dficult” to secure an election. The Shadow Chancellor said: If we can’t get our deal through Parliament, [we’ve] kept the option on the table of going back to the people in a public vote. Our preference is a general election, butthat’s not available to us, yeah, a People’s Vote. “At the moment it’s very dficult to seewe could a general election, we know that. So therefore, yes, maybewe can’t get our deal through Parliament, we’d go back to the people again. At a later event, Mr McDonnell added: “We are still in hope of a general election but it’s unlikely.”

He concluded the statement telling officers he did not go to the MacPhail family home and saidthey didn’t believe him “they could have my DNA”. The boy said he had contacted Aleshas dad. Robert MacPhail, and four or five other people he knew who sold cannabis to seehe could get any, and left the house on Ardbeg Road at about am. After the child’s body was found around am the officer was told about a kne being found on a beach opposite the MacPhail family home, near a bus shelter. Kate, , dazzled in a floor- Gucci gown as she joined senior women from the financial industry at the glittering event at the Victoria and Albert Museum. The Duchess of Cambridge, the guest of honour, will attend a private reception before making a short speech ahead of the dinner. Kate arrived in a powder pink and cream Gucci gown for the evening engagement with her hair half up, half down. Her shoes are Oscar de la Renta, accompanied with a Prada bag. Inside, the Duchess was greeted by Dr Tristram Hunt, Director of the VA, of which she is patron, and Colonel Jane Davis, Vice Lord Lieutenant of Greater London. She then joined WF’s CEO Amanda Pullinger and Lauren Malafronte, Chair of its Global Association Board, telling them: “This time last year I was still pregnant!”   Kate, who along with her husband William and brother-in-law Harry is patron of  Women in Finance’s Philanthropic Initiatives, has attended three previous galas held by the organisation in aid of charities associated with the young royals. In  she was the guest of honour at a dinner in aid of The Art Room in  she joined a fundraiser for Action on Addiction in  she and her husband the Duke attended a dinner on behalf of Child Bereavement UK. Other  Women in Finance gala dinners have generated hundreds of thousands of pounds for William’s SkillForce and Wellchild, of which the Duke of Sussex is patron.  Women in Finance, previously known as  Women in Hedge Funds isa leading non-profit organisation for professionals in the alternative investments industry.  Each year, WFs Board of Directors selects a beneficiary for its philanthropic initiatives, which cover womens and family health, mentoring and education programmes. Mentally Healthy Schools is a free, expert-backed online resource, which provides advice, information and practical tools – such as lesson and assembly plans – to help primary school teachers, leaders and staff support children’s wellbeing. The project – a legacy of the Heads Together campaign – was developed by the youth-focused charity partners of Heads Together the Anna Freud National Centre for Children and Families, PlaceBe and Young Minds.  It was launched by the Duchess of Cambridge in January  during a visit to Roe Green Junior School in Brent, north London. Launching the pilot website last year, the Duchess said: “I see time and time again that there is so much to be gained from taking the mental health of our children as seriously as we do their physical health.  “When we intervene early in le, we help avoid problems that are much more challenging to address in adulthood.” As many as one in  children will experience a mental health issue before the age of  and more than half of all mental health problems in adult le begin before the age of .   The gala is also an opportunity for WF to honour a leading woman in the financial world, Dame Minouche Shafik,Director of the London School of Economics and Political Science . She will be presented with the  Women in Finance  European Industry Leadership Award during the event. Speaking ahead of the gala, Amanda Pullinger, CEO of  Women in Finance, said: “Our Philanthropic Themes areWomen’s  Family Health, Education and Investing in the Next Generation . “It’s raising money but also raising awareness for the next generation of women who can see that there is a place for them in these leadership roles.” With a focus on female empowerment, could the Duchess of Sussex be the next member of the royal family to attend a WF gala  “We will seeshe takes that on,” said Amanda.

story: NewsHow Meghan Markle and Prince Harry are spending first Valentines Day as married coupleMeghan Markle and Prince Harry are enjoying their first Valentines Day as a married couple - and we hope its extra specialShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience EditorHayley Coyle:,  FEB NewsMeghan loves Valentines Day "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIts a very exciting time for Meghan Markle and Prince Harry as they prepare to welcome their first child and move house. But while royal fans probably hoped they would take some time out to celebrate their first Valentines Day as a married couple, they will actually be spending the day apart. Harry will spend the day in Norway visiting a remote training camp  miles inside the Arctic Circle. Meghan is a huge fan of the day, and has previously written: Hook, line and sinker, I am such a sucker for Valentines Day, so we expect it was a disappointing diary clash. title: ian bradys two locked briefcases
story: NewsIan Bradys two locked briefcases could reveal victims burial site - but may never be openedPolice have tried and failed to get a search warrant to go through the late serial killer’s possessionsShareCommentsByStephen White:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsBrady died, aged , from cancer and emphysema in Ashworth Hospital - and the clues to where Keith Bennett is buried may have died with him "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo briefcases Moors murderer Ian Brady had locked away on his deathbed may never be opened despite claims the contents could reveal where his victim Keith Bennett was buried. Brady demanded his locked briefcases be taken from his room at Ashworth Hospital on Merseyside and put into storage in the hours before he died in May . Police have tried and failed to get a search warrant to go through the serial killer’s possessions. Keith’s brother Alan has said there is a ‘desperate’ need to examine the killer’s s paperwork because he took the secret of the -year-old’s final resting place on Saddleworth Moor with him to the grave. But a district judge at Manchester Magistrates’ Court turned down a police application to search them after he died of cancer because the killer and Myra Hindley are dead there is no chance of a prosecution.   Detectives had argued they only learned about them when Brady passed away - but the court defeat and further legal advice persuaded them not to go to the High Court. A Greater Manchester Police spokesman said “The application [for a search warrant] was heard by a district judge on May , . Based on legal advice the force did not proceed to the High Court.” Officers also asked Robin Makin, Brady’s solicitor of  years who also controls his will, to let them inspect the briefcases and paperwork but he also refused. Brady was jailed for le in  and spent the next  years taunting his victims’ families, telling police he was ‘puzzled’ they never found Keith’s remains and in  even took officers on to the moor.   His accomplice Myra Hindley was also taken back to Saddleworth in the s when they discovered the remains of Pauline Reade - but never any trace of Keith. His brother Alan Bennett said: “There is a desperate need to look for anything that may help in the recovery of Keith’s body and there may be something in those cases. “My brother’s body still remains on the moor while all the other victims have been ed to their loved ones for a proper burial. There seems to be no compassion or thought for Keith or his family.” He added that he had correspondence with Brady while he was alive and the serial killer told him there were ‘instructions’ for him in his will. He has made a ‘personal plea’ to Mr Makin by email and letter but claims he has heard nothing.  Brady died, aged , from cancer and emphysema in Ashworth Hospital. Greater Manchester Police have said they will never close the case despite Brady’s death. Keith Bennett disappeared on the way to his grandmother’s house on June  . Hindley had lured him into her car and driven him to the Moors where he was murdered. The schoolboy’s mother, Winnie Johnson, died in  after battling cancer and fought tirelessly for decades to find her son and provide a Christian burial.  Brady and Hindley’s victims were: Pauline Reade, , was Brady and Hindley’s first victim. She was on her way to a local dance when Hindley persuaded her to get in her car. They drove Pauline to Saddleworth Moor where she was raped, beaten and stabbed. John Kilbride, , was snatched from Ashton market on Saturday November , . He was strangled and buried in a shallow grave. He was the second of Brady and Hindley’s five victims. Keith Bennett, , disappeared on the way to his grandmother’s house. Hindley had lured him into her car and driven him to the Moors where he was murdered. The method of killing has never been made clear. The pair buried his body which has never been found. Lesley Ann Downey, , disappeared on Boxing Day. She had been snatched from the fair and taken back to Hindley’s house. She was brutally assaulted with the ordeal captured on tape. Edward Evans, , was the sick duo’s final victim.He had just been to see Manchester United play when Brady lured in Edward. Brady repeatedly bludgeoned Evans with an axe.

story: NewsMum may have had epileptic fit before crash that killed her and son, fiveRebecca Smith was seen by a witness with her head down, twitching with foam in her mouth after crashing head on into a van in Draycott, Stoke on Trent, an inquest heardShareCommentsByRuby Davies:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsRebecca Smith was diagnosed with epilepsy as a teenager "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum may have had an epileptic seizure at the wheel before crashing head on into a van - killing herself and her five-year-old son, an inquest heard.Rebecca Smith was diagnosed with epilepsy aged  and witnesses described her as having a fit at the scene of the crash on August  last year. A witness said he saw her head was down to the left side and was twitching and she had foam in her mouth.Tests also revealed she was twice the legal drug-drive limit for cannabis, Stoke on Trent Live reports. Little Corey Rhodes was given first aid by witnesses at the scene but sadly he couldnt be saved and died shortly after arriving at the Royal Stoke University Hospital.Rebecca, fromFenton, died after undergoing emergency surgery in hospital a day later. Her six-year-old son Kyle Rhodes, who was also in the car, survived after being airlted to Sheffield. The -year-olds BMW had veered on to the other side of Uttoxeter Road, Draycott, before hitting the Mercedes Sprinter van as she made her way to Poundland in Uttoxeter. According to a witness, the driver of the van was on the phone to the emergency services who repeated I couldnt stop. Another, Craig Barks, claimed he saw the van lt up in the air following the impact.   In a statement, he said: I was travelling along Uttoxeter Road towards the A in a Citroen Picasso. I was driving behind a Mercedes Sprinter at mph. I heard an almighty bang and I saw the van in front of me lt up about four or five feet from the surface. I got out of the van and approached a silver car and saw a woman sat in the drivers seat. She appeared to be fitting as her head was down to the left side and was twitching and she had foam in her mouth. Witness Linda Woolliscroft was travelling in the same direction as Rebecca in her Land Rover when she heard a loud bang. In a statement read out at the hearing, she said: I saw a car approaching from behind, it was a silver car that I thought was going to overtake me. Then I heard an almighty bang and I wasnt sure what had caused the bang. I looked across and noticed there had been a crash. I parked my car on a grass verge, put my hazards on and went over to try to help. I noticed it was the silver car that was behind me moments before. I noticed there were two young children in the back of the car and the driver of the van was on the phone to the emergency services who repeated I couldnt stop. I went over to the BMW and one man was trying to assess those in the car. I noticed the young boys in the back and they started CPR on Corey.  The inquest heard it is not known whether Rebecca suffered a fit before the crash or as a result of the accident. But her long-term partner James Rhodes revealed that while visiting his surviving son in hospital, Kyle told him Rebecca had suffered a fit. He said: As soon as I walked through the door, the first thing he said to me was mums had a fit and that she had no hands on the steering wheel. He would have seen Becky having fits before and he knows what one is. James added: She started to suffer some more regular fits about eight months before she died in the early part of last year. When I was at work the kids would tell me she had a fit and they were around once every three months. On the one occasion she had three fits in one day. Her medication was increased and she still had fits. She took her medication but sometimes shed miss it. Becky didnt use any illegal drugs apart from having around three cannabis cigarettes a night when the kids had gone to bed. Corey was in reception and was a happy-go-lucky child. Kyle would always wear his seat belt, but Corey from time to time would put part of the belt behind his neck. Corey and Kyle could be a distraction in the carthey were fighting as five and six-year-old brothers do.  Collision investigator PC Roger Wetton said that there was no evidence that Rebecca had informed the DVLA about her epilpesy. PC Wetton said: The BMW drove along the central hatch marks into the lane of the Mercedes. The van driver didnt see it as a problem until he had insufficient time to. A collision occurred between the front of both vehicles, both rotated in an anti-clockwise direction. Witnesses say the driver appeared to be having a fit. Her condition was not disclosed to the DVLA, which would have resulted in her licence being removed. PC Wetton added both Kyle and Corey were not in child booster seats. He said: Neither child had a hard seat and Corey was not wearing his seatbelt properly which could have protected him from hitting the rear of the front seat. Assistant Coroner for North Staffordshire David James recorded that both Rebecca and Corey died from multiple injuries as a result of a road traffic collision.

story: NewsTeens head blows up like balloon after allergic reaction to hair dyeGeorgina Paraskeva claims she left with scorched and blistered skin after using a commercial hair dye product - so now uses coffee to colour her hair insteadShareCommentsByHelen Le Caplain:,  FEB NewsGeorgina Paraskeva believes the shocking reaction was to hair dye "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A teenager who claims he head swelled double its size using hair dye said she is now using coffee granules to colour her hair instead. Georgina Paraskevas said she was left looking like a monster after having an allergic reaction to what she said was Clairols Nice N Easy product last November. The -year-old claims the dye left her blind for two days and with a scorched scalp. Georgina, from Bristol, believes the reaction was to Paraphenylenediamine- a chemical commonly found in dark hair dyes. The online jewellery store owner is now speaking out about her terrying experience to ensure other people know of the potential risks and are aware of alternatives.  It was honestly the most horric experience of my le, Georgina said. Looking back at the pictures now is just horrible, my head doubled in size and I looked like a monster. It felt horrible and made me feel like I had zero confidence. I hated going out and felt really self-conscious and like people were staring at me. I made the conscious decision to stay inside as I hated going outside and feeling like people were looking at me, it was awful. Georgina was refreshing her hair colour using the Clairol black hair dye on November th - a product shed previously used with no problem - and claims her face and scalp suffered no adverse reaction.  However the following evening during a romantic meal with partner Josh Cox, , she said her head began to feel really hot and itchy. Over the next two days her face slowly started to balloon so panicked Georgina rang  where an operator advised taking an antihistamine to combat the swelling. After visiting her GP the following day and receiving cream to soothe her scorched and blistered skin her face continued to swell so much so her eyelids closed over leaving her unable to see. Georginas desperate mum bakery worker June Kellett, , rang for an ambulance on and was rushed to Southmead Hospital where she was hooked up to a drip. Georgina said: My whole family use Nice N Easy and Ive used it a few times before with no problems. That evening my head was absolutely fine but it was when I went out in the evening the following day my whole head was hot and seriously itchy.  I had blisters on my scalp and the skin on my hairline was really crispy. Later that week the swelling got worse and when my eyes started to swell up and I couldnt open them, thats when I felt really panicked. When I went to the hospital it felt like I had glass in my eyes and I went full-on blind. I couldnt see a thing for two days, it was horrible.  After being discharged from hospital with a antihistamine and steroid prescription, Georgina had to be cared for by her mum and partner as her vision was still affected for a few days. Three months on Georgina now avoids chemical hair dyes and uses coffee granules to tint her brunette locks. Georgina said: Ive started using natural remedies on my hair now and use coffee granules to colour it, it works really well. I want people to be aware that things like this can and do actually happen. A lot of people dont realise whats in hair dye and that it can be really dangerous, Im really lucky and super grateful that it didnt escalate. Since this happened Ive read up on it and I could have permanently lost my eyesight and its scary to see that people have died from it.  Im also a lot more cautious about the things I use on my skin and I just make sure I read everything and make sure it contains natural ingredients. A Clairol spokesperson said: The safety of the people who use our products is our first and most important priority, so we were very concerned to hear about Ms Paraskevas experience with Nicen Easy No Ammonia when we were first made aware of the incident last November. Unfortunately we were unable to get in touch with Ms Paraskeva at the time. Allergic reactions are very rare and hair colourants are extensively researched to ensure they are safe when used as directed and it is imperative patch tests are conducted at least  hours before each colouring occasion. Details of how to perform this test are included with each of our products to help minimise risk to consumers. We remain happy to discuss the matter with Ms Paraskeva should she wish to contact us on our customer helpline.

title: 8 things women need keep
story: News things all women need to do to keep their vagina healthy - including a golden ruleStephanie Taylor, managing director of Kegel, is trying to get women to look after their own intimate areas this year with her  simple tipsShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsShes revealed  simple tips for all women"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWith Valentines Day just around the corner lots of women are focusing on romantic gestures for their other halves. But according to a womens heath expert, we should all be focusing on something much more important than roses, date nights and sexy underwear this year. Stephanie Taylor, managing director ofKegel, is trying to get women looking after their own intimate areas. She says: Every woman dreams of being treated like a goddess on Valentines Day. Yet, many of us are guilty of not looking after number one…our vaginas. The happiness and health of your intimate body parts should be high up on your list of priorities all year around, just like looking after your skin, hair and nails.   To help woman look after their vaginas, Stephanie has shared a list of  tips she claims every woman should follow. . Save, dont shave While some women may feel cleaner, more comfortable or even sexier when they shave, pubic hair does serve a purpose.It protects from bacteria and infections such asFolliculitis, absorbs sweat and acts as a buffer against friction. A recent survey found  per cent of woman shave down there, and  per cent getting rid of everything - so this is something lots of people need to focus on. . Stay balanced You might not know it, but vaginas are actually self-cleaning thanks to good bacteria known asLactobacilli. Using perfumed shower gels, bubble baths, moisturisers and wipes can upset your carefully balanced pH levels, potentially leaving you withuncomfortablethrushorbacterial vaginosis. So, next time you’re in the supermarket, opt for a perfume-free or sensitive products.   . Brief encounters Stephanies next tip involved that cheeky underwear set youve bought for your other half... Sexy underwear and Valentine’s Day go hand in hand but the last thing you want is your fun ruined by a Urinary Tract Infection. When it comes to pelvic health, some underwear is better for you than others. Typically, thongs are tight-fitting and sit close to the skin, moving back and forth throughout the day which can contribute to a UTI. No matter what underwear you prefer, always opt for cotton, which is the most breathable fabric, helping to keep moisture at bay. . Hello hydration We all know drinking lots of water is important, but did you know its vital for a healthy vagina  Stephanie explains: Hitting the daily recommended HO level can be a struggle, butthe promise of glowing skin and more energy doesnt incentivise you, maybe your vagina might.  If youre dehydrated, the drier youll be down there, which could lead to issues like an infection, itching or burning. Depending on how active you are, you should aim to drink between two and three litres of water a day.If the thought of tap water bores you, jazz it up with citrus fruits, cucumber and mint. . The Golden Rule Stephanie has one Golden Rule when it comes to keeping things happy down there. She says: While there are many sex myths, you should believe this one…peeing after sex. That’s because clearing your bladder instantly flushes out any bacteria in your vagina and urinary tract, cutting your risk of getting a UTI. You may not feel the sensation to go immediately after, but dont worry, as long as its done within a reasonable amount of time you can relax. . Change after the gym According to Stephanie, staying in your gym clothes after your work out is a sin.   She says: The thought of brunch after a sweaty workout might be a great motivator but staying in your gym clothes for too long is a sin. Sweaty clothes and underwear create the perfect breeding ground for bad bacteria, particularlythey’re tight and made from latex or polyester. So, have a quick shower and put on fresh clothes before you get on with the rest of your day. . Work your pelvic floor Pelvic floor weakness is often thought of as an old woman problem but the truth is it can affect any woman at any point in her le. If you ignore your pelvic floor, you could end up with bladder incontinence, prolapse or a loss of sensation during sex.  Pelvic floor exercises should be part of your daily routine andyou need an extra helping hand, try a pelvic toner which uses electrical impulses to stimulate those all-important muscles. . Get to know your flow Stephanies final tip is an important one, and its all about your periods.She says: Periods arent always predictable. If you often find yourself caught short or waiting and waiting, download a fertility tracking app to help you keep tabs on your cycle. When your flow does start itll be at its heaviest for the first day or two.Make sure to change your pad frequentlyand opt for a thicker night-time towel. If you prefer tampons, always use the smallest size you can and never leave one in longer than eight hours to avoid putting yourself at risk ofToxic Shock Syndrome .

story: NewsIncredible moment baby boy born INSIDE amniotic sac in rare one in , caseBirth photographer Jana Brasil captured Monyck Valascos C-section delivery as little Noah was pulled from her body surrounded by amniotic fluidShareCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsBaby Noah was born inside the amniotic sac "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA newborn has arrived in the world while still inside his amniotic sac in what doctors believe is a one in , chance. The incredible images were taken as mother Monyck Valasco gave birth to little Noah in Brazil. Birth photographer Jana Brasil captured the baby completely surrounded by the amniotic fluid which had protected it during the pregnancy. Noahs whole body is engulfed by the sac but he still wiggles and attempts to cry as he is pulled from his mothers body. The sac usually splits just before birth and is more commonly known as a womans waters breaking. His -year-old mother told reporters at the Praia da Costa Hospital in the city of Vila Velha: People all around the world are reposting the photos and looking for us. I saw him being born. They lowered the screen so I could see. I cried a lot. Its an emotion that has no size.  Ms Brasil, who dedicated herself to photographing births as a full-time job three years ago, said: Its indescribable to register that moment. Last year I took photos of babies in the sacs, I have two awards. But nothing like the photo of Noah, it surprised me. I thought I had been through all the emotions, but he pulled a face and did a little pout.   Gynaecologist Rafael Angelo Baggieri said: An en-caul birth occurs when the baby is born without breaking the amniotic sac, in other words, within a little house which shelters it during gestation. Mr Baggieri says the special births occur in every , to , births and do not put the baby or mother at risk. Noah is reportedly still in hospital as Mr Baggieri said the newborn was tired after the birth but the tot is expected to be allowed to go home by the end of the week.  Back in August , a baby was filmed when it was born while still inside the amniotic sac. It is not known where the baby was born or how much he weighed. In the footage the newborn can be seen trying to stretch out asit was still inside its mother.

title: mh370 flight mystery was definitely
story: NewsMH flight mystery was definitely murder-suicide claims aviation expertFormer air crash investigator Larry Vance said the Malaysian Airline plane was stolen by either the pilot or co-pilot in what he called a criminal eventShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video what-really-happened-to-mh-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A Canadian aviation expert claims Malaysian Airline flight MH was crashed deliberately in a murder-suicide.Former air crash investigator Larry Vance said he was certain that either Capt. Zaharie Ahmad Shah or co-pilot Fariq Abdul Hamid stole the plane in what he termed a criminal event.The fateful flight took off from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing on March ,  but vanished without a trace with  crew and passengers on board.Vance, formerly of the Transportation Safety Board of Canada, told CBC News: It’s not an accident. This was planned and conducted, carried out by one inidual who had control of the aeroplane via his job to have control of the plane. He claimed that the pilot or co-pilot made the decision to take it to a remote part of the ocean and make it disappear forever.   After studying the crash debris, Vance claims the sections of the flap system were positioned downwards and that the plane entered the water at a low speed. He said: I believe with  percent certainty that the aeroplane entered the water in a controlled ditching with the flaps extended. This indicates the pilot had deliberately crashed the aircraft into the sea, he claims. We would call that a controlling ditching into the water, Vance told  Minutes Australia in an interview. The only way that could happen issomeone was flying the aeroplane. In particular,somebody selected the flaps to be in the extended position.  He added: If the flaps were down, then somebody would have had to have put them down, and they had to have put them down intentionally. Vance has put forward the theory in his book MH Mystery Solved which he spent  months researching. The investigator was not part of the official investigation by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau Bureau but teaches the details of the incident to students.   Vances theory has not been universally accepted by those connected to the case. Martin Dolan, former head of the Australian Transport Safety Bureau, there was not enough evidence to support a murder-suicide conclusion - adding that it was speculation that the flap system was positioned downwards. The evidence is not yet sufficient to draw as firm a conclusion as you appear to have done, he told Minutes.  MHs disappearance has resulted in numerous theories as to its eventual fate, including some which say the plane was switched on autopilot and ran out of fuel.Indonesian fisherman Rusli Khusmin, , claims his crew witnessed the disaster while on an expedition off the coast of northern Sumatra, Indonesia.He stated that the stricken plane emitted black smoke as it plunged into the Straight of Malacca in .  Speaking at a press conference in Kuala Lumpur, he said: I saw the plane moving from left to right like a broken kite. There was no noise, just black smoke as a result of fires before it crashed into the water. He swore an oath on the Koran and handed over evidence supporting his claims, including a a GPS navigator which he used to record the coordinates of the spot where he believes tyhe pane went down.

title: dundee potter to make city visit after appearing on bbcs the victorian house of arts and crafts
story: A Dundee potter is set to turn up the heat following his appearance on a hit BBC Two show.Stephen Winstanley, who recently starred in The Victorian House of Arts and Crafts, will visit Jessie’s Kitchen in Broughty Ferry on Saturday.The -year-old will be bringing along his Raku kiln as he demonstrates techniques for sculpting pots.Stephen – who previously worked as a kitchen porter in Jessie’s – said the method, popularised in Asia, dates back to the th Century.He said he was looking forward to ing to his old work as he talked about his recent stint on TV.The show is based around the Victorian era and looks at arts and crafts used during that time in history.Presenters Anita Rani and Keith Brymer Jones accompany six craft experts as they practise arts and crafts like wallpaper printing, furniture building and ceramic design, formerly used by famous sculpters from the Victorian era.Stephen said: “I heard about the show after I was given a poster from The McManus about a TV show looking for craft people.“I had an interview on Skype and I got cast for it there and then.“It has been on TV in the last few weeks, the filming was done in Chepstow in Wales.“We were taken back into this Victorian arts and crafts bubble.“It was seven days a week. We were based down there for the filming, which was done in September of last year.”The former Duncan of Jordanstone art and design student started sculpting at the age of .He added: “I’d spoken with Ross, the co-owner at Jessie’s.“He said it would be good to come and do a talk about what I do.”Pots are cooked at more than , degrees before being dipped in sawdust. The pot is then starved of oxygen, creating a glaze effect.Jessie’s co-owner, Ross Turrf, said there will be two sessions this Saturday.He said: “Stephen worked in our kitchen for around six months or so.“The last episode aired last week and we decided to get in touch with Stephen to seehe fancied coming in.“There will be two sessions, one at around .am and another at .pm and entry to the event is free.”

title: dundee student to umpire a prestigious european hockey tournament in austria
story: An Abertay sports student has been selected to umpire a prestigious European hockey tournament in Vienna.Carly Edward, , from Broughty Ferry, is going to officiate matches at the Women’s Euro Hockey Indoor Club Trophy competition running this weekend.The fourth-year sport and exercise student will travel to Austria today.She said she was excited about the chance to take part in such an important competition.“It’s my first time officiating an indoor tournament so I don’t know what to expect,” she said.“The national association put me forward to be an umpire at the event and each nation will have an umpire there. I’ll be representing Dundee as well – it’s always good when somewhere smaller gets recognised.”Carly, who started playing hockey at  at Grove Menzieshill Hockey Club, said her bigger goal is to end up as an umpire at the Olympics.She said: “I want to go to Austria and get noticed. I want to show people what I’m capable of and would like to be at  Olympics.”Carly got her start by becoming involved in youth Scottish Cup games and tournaments.In , she became a nationally appointed umpire and by the next summer she had umpired every national level from U  to seniors as well her first international tournament – the U  Women’s Euro Hockey Championships II in the Czech Republic.She added: “You have to be so focused all the time but I absolutely love what I do.“At the moment there’s a shortage of female umpires in our sport and I want people to know that it is an option worth considering.”Carly, whose boyfriend Lewis plays for Dundee Wanderers, said the sport provides friendly competition, as they represent rival clubs.She added: “I definitely won’t umpire his games!”

title: dundee uniteds mark connolly impressed with quality at tanandice as club unites
story: Recent recruit Mark Connolly believes Dundee United added real quality in the January transfer window but insist there is no “them and us” between the new arrivals and the players who were already on the books.The former Crawley Town and Kilmarnock defender says the aim of getting the Tangerines back to where they belong in the Premiership will be achieved through a group effort.The experienced Irishman has turned in two highly-impressive performances against Morton and St Mirren since his deadline-day arrival.And fellow-new men like Peter Pawlett, Mark Reynolds and Cammy Smith have also shone in those victories.The -year-old is quick to point out that, while the spotlight has been on them, the team as a whole has earned the recent success.“Dundee United is a very big club and, unfortunately, we’re in the league where we don’t want to be,” he said.“That’s the reason why myself and quite a few others have come in to help the boys already here and move up and get back to where we should be.“We are here to add to the players already here because, on top of all the boys who’ve just come in, we have very good players here.“We’ve only trained a few times together but you can see the quality that’s here and I think the manager has added just that bit more bite to help the football club.”Connolly realises the changes manager Robbie Neilson made in January means it is going to take a while for the players to get to know each other’s games inside out.It’s a process, though, that has been done while winning games and, under Neilson, he believes that can continue to be the case.“There have been a lot of changes but we are professional enough to handle that.“Sometimes it’s an excuseyou don’t start well and say we’re a new team and will need time to gel.“We don’t have the time to do that and we have brought in players who have experience and quality.“The manager has been dferent class – he’s a top-quality manager and deserves to be in the top league.“Myself, the new boys and the boys already here can help him get there.”Performances like the weekend Scottish Cup success at the Buddies will help.Connolly feels it’s one that will have had others sitting up and taking notice.“First-half we did what we know we can do. Being on the pitch it certainly felt it could have been a lot more than - at the break.“We dominated the game and that gives you a bit of confidence, especially playing against a Premiership team.“Second half we knew St Mirren were going to come out and have a bit more about them.“They did, but we were dealing with it without any real problems.“Unfortunately for us, Calum Butcher got sent off when it was a - tackle in midfield and could have just been a yellow card.“But he got sent off and then we showed the character to stick in and win the game.“We were playing against a team from the level above us for about  minutes with  men. We rolled our sleeves up and got the result we deserved.”

title: far travelled dundee star ryan mcgowan says scots footballers are luckier than they think
story: Far-travelled Ryan McGowan believes Scottish footballers don’t realise how lucky they are as they make their way in the game without having to give up their home comforts.When the -year-old signed for Dundee on loan from Bradford City at the end of last month, it took his tally of clubs in a -year senior career to .And having turned out for outfits in his native Australia, Scotland, China, the United Arab Emirates and England during that period, he’s clocked up more air miles that your average long-haul airline pilot.Having always known he’d have to travel round the world to make a career in football, the Socceroo believes it’s made him more open to hop from one country to another.That, he’s learned, is in contrast to many of the friends he’s made here in Scotland.“Scottish kids probably don’t realise how lucky they are. They’ve got something like  full-time clubs within a three-hour drive of where they’ve grown up,” he said.“When I was growing up in Adelaide, we had one team and then it was a two-hour flight to the next closest.“Soyou weren’t good enough for that team, you had to work harder and be prepared to sht around.“I know boys here who only want to play for teams in or near Edinburgh – and they can.“Scottish boys are very lucky to have so many clubs and opportunities without having to move.”While he’s no regrets about his nomadic career, McGowan admits the chance to hang around in one place for a prolonged period is growing more attractive.Particularlythat place is here in Scotland, the country he regards as his adopted home.“I do sometimes think I’d love to sign a two or three-year contract somewhere again,” he added.“I would have probably have loved to have stayed on at Hearts for a couple of more seasons and I was enjoying my time at United when I was there but bids came in and were accepted.“And having an Australian passport does open doors in Asia, which is why I’ve ended up there a few times.”If the chance arises to stay at Dundee long-term, he admits it’s something he will give serious thought.He has not, and will not, look that far ahead until he’s helped the Dark Blues out of their current predicament.“A couple of weeks ago moving to Dundee hadn’t even come onto my horizon. Everything has happened quickly and I just want to make sure that, first and foremost, we stay in this league.“When the summer comes,an opportunity arises to stay I will definitely consider it but there is a lot of work to be done between now and then.”He is confident by the end of the season Dundee will be safe.“It’s been really good so far. They are a great bunch of boys and they have made me feel really welcome in the dressing-room.“I’ve kicked most of them when I was playing here in seasons gone by so I know most of them.“There’s a good manager in Jim McIntyre to work under as well. I’m showing my age here but I’ve actually played against him when I was a young player on loan at Ayr from Hearts.“He was coming to the end of his career then and later I played against a couple of his teams once he’d become a manager.“I’m quite close with a couple of players who have played under him and they spoke highly of him and that was more of a factor in coming here.“Having played across the road I also knew how big a club Dundee is. It’s a good club, in a dficult position at the minute but definitely one we can get out of.”

title: george cran dundee are in a far better place now than when jim mcintyre arrived
story: Almost four months into his reign as Dundee manager, Jim McIntyre won’t look back on his first match in charge with too much fondness.However, he might just do so with a great deal more satisfaction with how his squad has shaped up in the time since.Despite only picking up two wins and six draws in the  matches under McIntyre, there’s a growing sense of optimism at Dens Park after some encouraging displays since the January transfer window.The opposite can be said of Saturday’s opponents Livingston, the side the Dark Blues faced in Jim’s debut in the dugout.After a lightning-fast start to theirto the Premiership – which peaked with that - thumping of Dundee back in October – Livi’s form has slipped off a clf with last Wednesday’s - draw at Hearts bringing a five-game losing streak to an end.Since leaving Dundee gaffer Jim in no doubt how big a job he had on his hands with that - success at the Tony Macaroni Arena, Gary Holt’s side have only picked up three victories and none since the middle of December.That’s seen them slip from a high of second spot with  points from their first eight games down to ninth with just  picked up from the following  matches.And, though the gap between the sides hasn’t shrunk in those four months, the feeling around both clubs right now couldn’t be more dferent.A massive part of that from Dundee’s point of view is the complete overhaul of the playing squad in the winter transfer window.In fact, there’s a fair chance there won’t be any of the players who featured in the - defeat the last time the Dark Blues travelled to West Lothian this time around.Only three of the  used by Jim that day remain at the club – Elliott Parish, Cammy Kerr and Kenny Miller.Of those, only Miller looks like he could be given a start this time around but even he has a fair bit of competition to overcome with Andrew Nelson on the goal trail and Craig Curran preferred by the manager to lead the line in every match since he arrived at the club at the start of January.A missed penalty in stoppage time in their last run-out won’t have helped veteran Miller’s cause either.Meanwhile, Parish hasn’t featured since that - thumping and doesn’t look like dislodging Seny Dieng as first choice any time soon.The nature of the goals that day, with all four from set-pieces, no doubt led the manager to question his defenders.Parish quickly paid the price by dropping to the bench while three of the back four have been moved on.Andy Boyle is now at Ross County, Ryan Inniss was sent back to Crystal Palace after a nightmare at Palmerston in the Scottish Cup and Calvin Miller has also dropped to the Championship, being picked up by Ayr United on loan from Celtic.Kerr was right-back in October but he’s seen his place taken by new signing James Horsfield in recent games.The former Manchester City kid has looked assured in Kerr’s place and will take some shting before Saturday.The rest of the team have since been shown the exit door – Glen Kamara, Kharl Madianga, Lewis Spence, Sofien Moussa, Benjy Kallman, Roarie Deacon and Adil Nabi have all moved on.Even the side that drew - with Livi at Dens on Boxing Day will be unrecognisable to the one running out this weekend.Whatever side he opts for, Jim knows his team are in a far better place than when he took over – now they have to prove that by getting points on the board.

title: st mirrens paul mcginn spared action after elbowing dundee uniteds cammy smith
story: St Mirren defender Paul McGinn will face no further punishment after his arm caught Dundee United’s Cammy Smith in the face during the clubs’ Scottish Cup fth round tie on Saturday.The Buddies full-back was cautioned after his elbow made contact with his former Paisley team-mate early in the second half as St Mirren crashed out of the cup - to Robbie Neilson’s Championship outfit.Referee Willie Collum was just yards away from the collision and only deemed the offence worthy of a yellow card.Even though the foul was seen by the referee, under SFA rules compliance officer Clare Whyte could have issued a notice of complaint to the former Dundee full-back had she decided the incident was “exceptional in nature”.A  of three former referees would also have to have given their unanimous agreement McGinn deserved to be sent off for Whyte to proceed with a notice of complaint but it has been decided there was not enough evidence.

title: tom duthie this time the renewed hope at dundee united might not be a false dawn
story: For the first time in a long time, perhaps even since the dark days of relegation in , there is strong reason for optimism at Dundee United.The one thing that should be stressed about that immediately is it’s still early days.Robbie Neilson’s rebuilt team is only two games in and that means there is some way to go before we can confirm things are definitely on the up at Tannadice.And the truth is that will only come with promotion back to the Premiership.It must also be said there have been other  dawns over the past three years.The arrival of Ray McKinnon and then Csaba Laslo as managers brought hope and even early promise that, after the disastrous   campaign, things were being turned around.In fairness to McKinnon in particular, had he been handed the kind of budget that was made available to the current team boss in the January transfer window, the major problems at the club might well have been sorted and the Tangerines could have been back in the top flight already.Unfortunately for him, those in the boardroom when he was in charge were unable to provide the kind of cash for signings new American owner Mark Ogren has.That, incidentally, is not a criticism of the previous regimes, just an unfortunate fact.Neilson has been lucky he’s got an owner with dollars to spend and the indications so far suggest that owner is just as fortunate that he has a manager who knows how to spend it wisely.Ogren can also consider himself blessed his predecessor in the chairman’s seat at Tannadice, Mike Martin, found not just a good manager, but one who through being out of the game for a period, had taken the time to look at United and form a clear picture of what was needed.Because one thing that’s obvious about the signings made is all have been part of a jigsaw in the manager’s mind.January  didn’t just come round and see Neilson turn his thoughts to what was available. He’d done his homework and, equally importantly, worked out exactly where his squad needed strengthening.That means the right players for the right positions have been found, or so it seems.That’s produced victories over Morton and St Mirren that have lted spirits among Arabs. Rightly so, because both outings have seen impressive work.Of course, with most of those brought in lacking match fitness – that’s usually the major issue with January signings – the good football, has mostly come in the first hour.Players who’ve not had a lot of game time have tired, particularly when reduced to  men at St Mirren. They’ve then shown their ability to manage matches.What the manager also looks to have done well is identy those already in his squad who were good enough to be part of his plans.For all new boys like Peter Pawlett, Mark Reynolds and Mark Connolly have deserved the praise they’ve received for their first couple of performances, attackers Pavol Safranko and Nicky Clark have shown they remain big players.After a run of just two goals in nine games, Safranko has found his scoring touch with one in each of the last two outings and has looked the lethal striker he did when he first arrived on loan from Aalborg.Now he’s finally got fully fit, Clark also looks dangerous and there’s no doubt both have benefited from having better players round them in the last two outings.For Neilson and his players the trick is now to keep the good work going. The good news for United fans is, this time, that might just happen.

title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Thursday  Feb  : PM

story: YOUNG business leaders in the Highlands are being offered a chance to join a highly personalised business growth programme to help drive their businesses forward.IMPACT organised by Highlands and Islands EnterprisersquosNorthern Innovation Hub, in partnership with consultancy business Anderson Anderson and Brown , is now offering  businesses an opportunity to engage in this first of its kind support programme.Julie Lat, of the House of Spice in Fort Augustus, was part of the year-long fully funded programmersquos first intake in November.She said: ldquoI have found IMPACT highly beneficial. title: Highland seafood firm goes into liquidation
story: A Highland seafood firm set up by an award-winning entrepreneur has gone into voluntary liquidation.Coast and Glen, founded by Magnus Houston in , had grown rapidly in recent years, supplying fresh fish and game to hotels and restaurants across the UK and had also expanded direct sales to consumers.The business, which employed nine people and had a turnover of pound. million, operated from fully-fitted leased premises in Alness and had also acquired a new  sq ft factory in Muir of Ord.Its liquidation was attributed to unsustainable cash flow problems stemming from rising costs, intense competition and very low margins.Mr Houston, a former motorcycle racer, taught himself the trade after a bad crash.His other business, Fishbox, is unaffected.Thursday  Feb  : PM
